awd_abstract_narration:
Portland Community College (PCC) Sylvania's Realizing Engineering Technology Achievement (RETA) project increases the number of educated and skilled engineering technology employees in the Portland metropolitan area, focusing on females and minorities underrepresented in STEM careers. The project provides scholarships to students enrolled in Civil/Mechanical Engineering Technology, Electronic Engineering Technology, and Machine Manufacturing Technology, with the expectation that four cohorts of 13 students will receive support for two years. Six scholars who transfer to Oregon Institute of Technology (OIT) seeking a baccalaureate degree will also receive a one-year scholarship. Scholarships will be awarded based upon academic achievement and financial need.  Additional program elements will help ensure that scholars are recruited and retained within the program. A cohort-building structure including monthly roundtables, sponsored events, mentoring and tutoring of first year scholars by second year scholars will cement relationships among scholars. Opportunities to strengthen interactions with PCC and OIT engineering faculty and industry representatives allows scholars the chance to be mentored by professionals while exploring further college and career options.

The project uses strategies developed by other NSF-sponsored initiatives on recruiting and retaining women and underrepresented minorities in engineering. Initiating these strategies in outreach materials and existing engineering courses broadens the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in the target programs. Additionally, it adds to the intellectual merit of the project and the engineering field overall by adding to the body of knowledge of what works in recruiting and retaining these target populations in STEM majors. PCC and OIT will collaborate in both formative and summative evaluations of the RETA project. The project will collect a variety of data including surveys, student records, and student tracking to evaluate the project's effectiveness.

por.por_cntn:
The Realizing Engineering Technology Achievement project provided scholarships to 66 students. These students were in the fields of Electronic Engineering Technology, Civil & Mechanical Engineering Technology (renamed during the grant to Civil & Construction Engineering Technology) and Machine Manufacturing Technology. All of the 66 students were enrolled in a 2-year program at Portland Community College seeking their Associates of Applied Science degrees in an engineering technology program or machine manufacturing. Upon completion of their degrees, students either found employment or continued on with our transfer college partner.   

The goals of this project were to lower barriers to participation in these programs in order to increase the employment of underrepresented students. The project provided mentoring activities, tutoring support and other activities that helped create connections and support for students. The grant also created professional development opportunities that faculty and staff could implement in order to shift the classroom experience for students by practicing equitable grading practices and creating opportunities for students to bring their interests into the classroom.

The project also addressed challenges that were created during the height of COVID-19 pandemic, by providing learning support for students through the use of personal use equipment trainers that were mailed to students. This allowed students to be able to continue their education from home during the timeframe when the pandemic kept programs from being taught on campus.  

Through the duration of our grant we increased the percentage of women in these programs from 10.1% to 19.3%. The percentage of underrepresented students has increased from 11.6% to 16.1%.  In addition to this increase in reach, 74% of the scholars graduated and 76% of those graduating scholars found employment or continued on with education following the completion of their degrees.


 

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Tara Nelson
